factoid: Prince Andrew looked out of the shed.
Prince Andrew saw Pierre.
Pierre had tripped over a pole on the ground.
Pierre had nearly fallen.
Pierre was coming his way to Prince Andrew.
It was unpleasant to Prince Andrew to meet people of his own set in general.
It was unpleasant to Prince Andrew to meet Pierre.
Pierre reminded Prince Andrew of all the painful moments of Prince Andrew's last visit to Moscow.
Prince Andrew said, "You? What a surprise!"
Prince Andrew asked, "What brings you here?"
Prince Andrew said, "This is unexpected!"
Prince Andrew's eyes and face expressed hostility.
Pierre noticed Prince Andrew's hostility at once.
Prince Andrew approached the shed full of animation.
Pierre approached the shed full of animation.
Pierre felt constrained and ill at ease when he saw Prince Andrew's face.
Pierre said, "I have come... simply... you know... come... it interests me."
Pierre had senselessly repeated the word "interesting" that day.
Pierre said, "I wish to see the battle."
Prince Andrew asked, "What do the Masonic brothers say about war?"
Prince Andrew asked, "How would they stop it?"
Prince Andrew asked, "How’s Moscow?"
Prince Andrew asked, "And my people?"
Prince Andrew asked, "Have they reached Moscow at last?"
Prince Andrew's tone was serious when asking about Moscow and his people.
Prince Andrew's people have reached Moscow.
Julie Drubetskáya told Prince Andrew that his people have reached Moscow.
Prince Andrew went to see his people.
Prince Andrew missed his people.
Prince Andrew's people have gone to his estate near Moscow.
The officers were about to take leave.
Prince Andrew was reluctant to be left alone with his friend.
Prince Andrew asked the officers to stay and have tea.
Seats were brought in.
Tea was brought in.
The officers gazed with surprise at Pierre’s huge stout figure.
The officers listened to Pierre's talk of Moscow.
The officers listened to Pierre's talk of the position of our army.
Pierre had ridden around the position of our army.
Prince Andrew remained silent.
Prince Andrew's expression was forbidding.
Pierre addressed his remarks chiefly to the good‑natured battalion commander.
Prince Andrew asked, "So you understand the whole position of our troops?"
Prince Andrew interrupted Pierre.
Pierre said, "Yes— that is, how do you mean?"
Pierre said, "Not being a military man I can’t say I have understood it fully."
Pierre said, "I understand the general position."
Prince Andrew said, "Well, then, you know more than anyone else, be it who it may."
Pierre looked over his spectacles in perplexity at Prince Andrew.
Pierre asked, "Well, and what do you think of Kutúzov’s appointment?"
Prince Andrew replied, "I was very glad of his appointment, that’s all I know."
Prince Andrew asked, "And tell me your opinion of Barclay de Tolly."
In Moscow, people are saying "heaven knows what about him."
Prince Andrew asked, "What do you think of him?"
Prince Andrew replied, "Ask them," indicating the officers.
Pierre looked at Timókhin.
Pierre had a condescendingly interrogative smile.
Timókhin said, "We see light again, since his Serenity has been appointed, your excellency."
Timókhin was timid.
Timókhin continually turned to glance at his colonel.
Pierre asked, "Why so?"
Timókhin said, "Well, to mention only firewood and fodder, let me inform you."
Timókhin said, "Why, when we were retreating from Sventsyáni we dare not touch a stick or a wisp of hay or anything."
Timókhin said, "You see, we were going away, so he would get it all; wasn’t it so, your excellency?"
Timókhin turned to the prince again.
Timókhin said, "But we daren’t."
In Timókhin's regiment, two officers were court-martialed for that kind of thing.
When his Serenity took command, everything became straightforward.
Now we see light.
Timókhin asked, "Then why was it forbidden?"
Timókhin looked about in confusion.
Timókhin did not know how to answer such a question.
Pierre asked the same question to Prince Andrew.
